text: Hope springs eternal.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A little learning is a dangerous thing.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A man should never be ashamed to own he has been in the wrong, which is but saying... that he is wiser today than he was yesterday.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Ambition first sprung from your blest abodes; The glorious fault of Angels and of Gods.
author: Alexander Pope

text: On life's vast ocean diversely we sail. Reasons the card, but passion the gale.
author: Alexander Pope

text: In pride, in reasoning pride, our error lies; All quit their sphere and rush into the skies. Pride still is aiming at the bless'd abodes, Men would be angels, angels would be gods.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Many men have been capable of doing a wise thing, more a cunning thing, but very few a generous thing
author: Alexander Pope

text: Thus sung the shepherds till th' approach of night, The skies yet blushing with departing light, When falling dews with spangles deck'd the glade, And the low sun had lengthened every shade.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Blessed is he who expects nothing, for he shall never be disappointed.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Good God! How often are we to die before we go quite off this stage? In every friend we lose a part of ourselves, and the best part
author: Alexander Pope

text: Do you find yourself making excuses when you do not perform? Shed the excuses and face reality. Excuses are the loser's way out. They will mar your credibility and stunt your personal growth.
author: Alexander Pope

text: An excuse is worse and more terrible than a lie; for an excuse is a lie guarded.
author: Alexander Pope

text: For virtue's self may too much zeal be had; the worst of madmen is a saint run mad.
author: Alexander Pope

text: It is with our judgments as with our watches: no two go just alike, yet each believes his own.
author: Alexander Pope

text: We think our fathers fools, so wise we grow. Our wiser sons, no doubt will think us so.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A person who is too nice an observer of the business of the crowd, like one who is too curious in observing the labor of bees, will often be stung for his curiosity.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Good God! How often are we to die before we go quite off this stage? In every friend we lose a part of ourselves, and the best part.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Honor and shame from no condition rise; act well your part, there all the honor lies.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Love, free as air at sight of human ties, Spreads his light wings, and in a moment flies.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The world forgetting, by the world forgot.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Two purposes in human nature rule. Self- love to urge, and reason to restrain.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Fools rush in where angels fear to tread.
author: Alexander Pope

text: And all who told it added something new, And all who heard it made enlargements too.
author: Alexander Pope

text: All gardening is landscape painting.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Hear how the birds, on every blooming spray, With joyous music wake the dawning day.
author: Alexander Pope

text: In cold December fragrant chaplets blow, And heavy harvests nod beneath the snow.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The most positive men are the most credulous.
author: Alexander Pope

text: He who tells a lie, is not sensible how great a task he undertakes; for he must be forced to invent twenty more to maintain that one.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A field of glory is a field for all.
author: Alexander Pope

text: At every word a reputation dies.
author: Alexander Pope

text: On wrongs swift vengeance waits.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The same ambition can destroy or save, and make a patriot as it makes a knave.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The hidden harmony is better than the obvious.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Our judgments, like our watches, none go just alike, yet each believes his ownâ€
author: Alexander Pope

text: To err is human, to forgive divine.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Our judgments, like our watches, none go just alike, yet each believes his own.
author: Alexander Pope

text: And, after all, what is a lie? 'Tis but the truth in a masquerade.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Conceit is to nature what paint is to beauty; it is not only needless, but impairs what it would improve.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Reason, however able, cool at best, Cares not for service, or but serves when prest, Stays till we call, and then not often near.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Never find fault with the absent.
author: Alexander Pope

text: To err is human; to forgive, divine.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Sickness is a sort of early old age; it teaches us a diffidence in our earthly state.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Death, only death, can break the lasting chain; And here, ev'n then, shall my cold dust remain.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Expression is the dress of thought.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A family is but too often a commonwealth of malignants.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Strength of mind is exercise, not rest.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The lights and shades, whose well-accorded strife gives all the strength and color of our life.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Charms strike the sight, but merit wins the soul.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A work of art that contains theories is like an object on which the price tag has been left.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The mouse that always trusts to one poor hol can never be a mouse of any soul.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The mouse that always trusts to one poor hole can never be a mouse of any soul.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Grave authors say, and witty poets sing, That honest wedlock is a glorious thing.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Authors, like coins, grow dear as they grow old: It is the rust we value, not the gold.
author: Alexander Pope

text: What Reason weaves, by Passion is undone.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Wit is the lowest form of humor.
author: Alexander Pope

text: True politeness consists in being easy one's self, and in making every one about one as easy as one can.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Though triumphs were to generals only due, crowns were reserved to grace the soldiers too.
author: Alexander Pope

text: 'Tis not enough your counsel still be true; Blunt truths more mischief than nice falsehoods do.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The vulgar boil, the learned roast, an egg.
author: Alexander Pope

text: To observations which ourselves we make, we grow more partial for th' observer's sake.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The whispering breeze pants on the leaves, and dies upon the trees.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Superstition is the spleen of the soul.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Genius creates, and taste preserves. Taste is the good sense of genius; without taste, genius is only sublime folly.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The worst of madmen is a saint run mad.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A king may be a tool, a thing of straw; but if he serves to frighten our enemies, and secure our property, it is well enough; a scarecrow is a thing of straw, but it protects the corn.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Like bubbles on the sea of matter borne, They rise, they break, and to that sea return.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Monuments, like men, submit to fate.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The greatest magnifying glasses in the world are a man's own eyes when they look upon his own person.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Some are bewildered in the maze of schools, And some made coxcombs nature meant but fools.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Satan is wiser now than before, and tempts by making rich instead of poor.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The soul's calm sunshine, and the heartfelt joy.
author: Alexander Pope

text: An atheist is but a mad, ridiculous derider of piety, but a hypocrite makes a sober jest of God and religion; he finds it easier to be upon his knees than to rise to a good action.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Praise undeserved, is satire in disguise.
author: Alexander Pope

text: And more than echoes talk along the walls.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Thus let me live, unseen, unknown, Thus unlamented let me die, Steal from the world, and not a stone Tell where I lie.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Say, will the falcon, stooping from above, Smit with her varying plumage, spare the dove? Admires the jay the insect's gilded wings? Or hears the hawk when Philomela sings?
author: Alexander Pope

text: There is a certain majesty in simplicity which is far above all the quaintness of wit.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Judges and senates have been bought for gold; Esteem and love were never to be sold.
author: Alexander Pope

text: But health consists with temperance alone, and peace, oh virtue! peace is all thy own.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Love seldom haunts the breast where learning lies, And Venus sets ere Mercury can rise.
author: Alexander Pope

text: I never knew any man in my life, who could not bear another's misfortunes perfectly like a Christian.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Amusement is the happiness of those who cannot think.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Whoever thinks a faultless piece to see, . Thinks what ne'er was, nor is, nor e'er shall be.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Some people will never learn anything, for this reason, because they understand everything too soon.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Fix'd like a plant on his peculiar spot, To draw nutrition, propagate and rot.
author: Alexander Pope

text: To be angry is to revenge the faults of others on ourselves.
author: Alexander Pope

text: They dream in courtship, but in wedlock wake.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Tell me, my soul, can this be death? . Lend, lend your wings! I mount! I fly! . O grave, where is thy victory? .
author: Alexander Pope

text: Our rural ancestors, with little blest, patient of labor when the end was rest, Indulged the day that housed their annual grain, with feasts, and off’rings, and a thankful strain.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Taste is a rare to be found as a true genius. That most men are born with some taste.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The younger brother hath the more wit.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Expression is the dress of thought, and still appears more decent as more suitable. A vile conceit in pompous words expressed, is like a clown in regal purple dressed.
author: Alexander Pope

text: O happiness! Our being's end and aim! For which we bear to live, or dare to die.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Some are bewilder'd in the maze of schools, . And some made coxcombs nature meant but fools.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The learned is happy, nature to explore, the fool Is happy, that he knows no more.
author: Alexander Pope

text: You think this cruel? take it for a rule, . No creature smarts so little as a fool.
author: Alexander Pope

text: A man should never be ashamed to admit he has been in the wrong, which is but saying, in other words, that he is wiser today than he was yesterday.
author: Alexander Pope

text: One of the things that I have almost most wondered at is, that there should be any such thing as human vanity. If I had any, I had enough to mortify it a few days ago, for I lost my mind for a whole day.
author: Alexander Pope

text: An honest man's the noblest work of God.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Do good by stealth, and blush to find it fame.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Chiefs who no more in bloody fights engage, But wise through time, and narrative with age, In summer days like grasshoppers rejoice. A bloodless race, that send a feeble voice.
author: Alexander Pope

text: Coffee, (which makes the politician wise, . And see thro' all things with his half-shut eyes).
author: Alexander Pope

text: The ruling passion, be it what it will, the ruling passion conquers reason still.
author: Alexander Pope

text: The best way to prove the clearness of our mind, is by showing its faults; as when a stream discovers the dirt at the bottom, it convinces us of the transparency and purity of the water.
author: Alexander Pope
